item.title: How I got R with tcl-tk on my Mac
item.description: Background Sometimes data is very skewed and contains a lot of ‘zeros’ (or very small numbers approaching ‘zero’). Before analyses such data need normalisation to meet the assumptions of a statistical test (you can find more on transformation and normalisation here). Usually people log-transform (e.g. natural log, or log2), the disadvantage is that you loose the ‘zeros’. In my case that is an issue, because the measurements made were properly done (no technical issues), so ‘zero’ really represents ‘zero’.

item.title: How I setup my Mac to do Science in 2018
item.description: Background I prefer to use brew to install the ‘missing’ libraries on macOS that come in handy, like weget, or imagemagick, or rename. In addition, I work on the analyses of histological slides, and for that I use slideToolkit which also requires brew on macOS. So, I thought, “might as well go full monty” and install R and RStudio using brew. This provides me with a powerful method to control many packages/libraries that are needed for macOS and at the same time creates a very clean R environment on my Mac.
